content: In a town, there are 3 doctors. Each doctor has 4 patients who visit them every day. If each patient visits the doctor for 15 minutes and the doctors work simultaneously, how long does it take for all the patients to be seen by their respective doctors?

First, I should figure out how many patients there are in total. Since there are 3 doctors and each has 4 patients, the total number of patients is 3 doctors times 4 patients per doctor, which is 12 patients.

Now, each patient needs 15 minutes with their doctor. But since the doctors are working simultaneously, they can see their patients at the same time.

So, each doctor has 4 patients, and each patient takes 15 minutes. If the doctor sees one patient at a time, then for 4 patients, it would be 4 times 15 minutes, which is 60 minutes or 1 hour per doctor.

But since all doctors are working at the same time, the time it takes for all patients to be seen is the same as the time it takes for one doctor to see all their patients, assuming that each doctor is seeing their patients one after another.
